maml:description.maml:para: This command uses computer objects created with Get-MyUptime to retrieve local time information.

maml:Description.maml:para: A computer object created with Get-MyUptime
A computer object created with Get-MyUptime

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $c = Get-MyUptime -computername chi-dc04,chi-p50,chi-hvr2 PS C:\> $c | get-mylocaltime
Computername LocalDateTime ------------ ------------- CHI-DC04 7/19/2016 12:37:27 PM CHI-P50 7/19/2016 12:37:27 PM CHI-HVR2 7/19/2016 12:37:27 PM

maml:description.maml:para: This command uses computer objects created with Get-MyUptime to retrieve time zone information.

maml:Description.maml:para: A computer object created with Get-MyUptime
A computer object created with Get-MyUptime

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $c = Get-MyUptime -computername chi-dc04,chi-p50,chi-hvr2 PS C:\> $c | get-mytimezone
Computername Caption CurrentTimeZone ------------ ------- --------------- CHI-DC04 (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada) -240 CHI-P50 (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada) -240 CHI-HVR2 (UTC-05:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada) -240

maml:description.maml:para: This command will query the Win32_OperatingSystem class using Get-CimInstance and write an uptime object to the pipeline. You must run this with credentials that have administrator rights on the remote computer.

This PowerShell function is designed to make it easy to get uptime information for one or more remote computers. The command uses the CIM cmdlets so any remote computer must be running at least PowerShell 3.0 with remoting enabled. You can use computer names or existing CIM sessions. If you use a computer name you can also test to see if it is PowerShell v3 compatible.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the computer to query. This parameter has an alias of CN and Name. The computer must be running PowerShell 3.0 or later with remoting enabled to support the CIM cmdlets.
Use Test-WSMan to verify computer can be reached and is running v3 or later of the Windows Management Framework stack.
The name of the computer to query. This parameter has an alias of CN and Name. The computer must be running PowerShell 3.0 or later with remoting enabled to support the CIM cmdlets.
Use Test-WSMan to verify computer can be reached and is running v3 or later of the Windows Management Framework stack.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-myuptime chi-dc01,chi-fp02
Computername LastRebootTime Days Hours Minutes Seconds ------------ -------------- ---- ----- ------- ------- CHI-DC01 7/18/2016 3:17:48 PM 0 21 8 39 CHI-FP02 6/15/2016 12:49:26 PM 33 23 37 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: Formatted results for multiple computers. You can also pipe computer names into this command.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-myuptime | format-list
Computername : WIN81-ENT-01 LastReboot : 7/15/2016 8:28:24 AM Uptime : 4.03:58:24.7545765

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get uptime for the local computer and use the custom list formatting view.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $c = "chi-dc01","chi-core01","chi-dc02","chi-hvr2","chi-dc04 PS C:\> $c | get-myuptime -test | Sort LastRebootTime -Descending
WARNING: CHI-DC02 is not accessible via the WSMan protocol.
Computername LastRebootTime Days Hours Minutes Seconds ------------ -------------- ---- ----- ------- ------- CHI-DC01 7/18/2016 3:17:48 PM 0 21 10 0 CHI-HVR2 7/18/2016 3:15:04 PM 0 21 12 47 CHI-CORE01 7/18/2016 3:14:57 PM 0 21 12 51 CHI-DC04 7/5/2016 4:20:18 PM 13 20 7 34

dev:remarks.maml:para: Query a list of computers, testing for WSMan and sort on the LastRebootTime

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> "chi-dc01","chi-core01","chi-hvr2","chi-dc04" | Get-myuptime | where Days -le 7
Computername LastRebootTime Days Hours Minutes Seconds ------------ -------------- ---- ----- ------- ------- CHI-DC01 7/18/2016 3:17:48 PM 0 21 11 36 CHI-CORE01 7/18/2016 3:14:57 PM 0 21 14 27 CHI-HVR2 7/18/2016 3:15:04 PM 0 21 14 21

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get uptime for a list of computers and filter out those that have been running for longer than 7 days.
The first command creates an array of computer names. The second command gets uptime but tests each computer first.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> get-myuptime "chi-dc01","chi-core01","chi-dc04" | Sort Uptime | Select Computername,Uptime
Computername Uptime ------------ ------ CHI-DC01 21:12:33.4281159 CHI-CORE01 21:15:24.2350091 CHI-DC04 13.20:10:03.9522704

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get uptime for a set of servers, sort on the uptime and display computername and uptime.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 6 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $cs = New-CimSession chi-dc01,chi-dc04,chi-core01 PS C:\> $cs | Get-MyUptime | Select Computername,Uptime
Computername Uptime ------------ ------ CHI-DC01 21:14:29.2166176 CHI-CORE01 21:17:20.0236754 CHI-DC04 13.20:11:59.7334703

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get uptime for a list of computers via CIM Sessions.

maml:description.maml:para: If you run Get-MyUptime and save the results to a variable, some properties like Uptime won't be updated the next time you look at the variable. You can use this command to refresh or update the MyUptime objects.

maml:Description.maml:para: A computer object created with Get-MyUptime
A computer object created with Get-MyUptime

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $b = Get-Myuptime chi-p50 PS C:\> $b | Select computername,uptime
Computername Uptime ------------ ------ CHI-P50 2.00:06:47.1523262
PS C:\> $b | Update-MyUptime PS C:\> $b | Select computername,uptime
Computername Uptime ------------ ------ CHI-P50 2.00:07:39.4540150
